So... Pick the right champions, build the right items, AND get a team of randoms to work together.  Yeah, that's the definition of healthy counterplay.

You're so defeatist. "Pick the right items?" Just build MR. How is that difficult? Banshee's Veil, Spirit Visage, Athene's Unholy Grail, Hexdrinker ->Maw of Malmortius. Pick any two.

"Pick the right champion?" Just pick your favorite and don't lock in right away. If you don't see any CC on your team, switch to your next favorite champ that has some CC. I chose Sona in all but 3 of the Hexakills I played. She has healing, speed buff, and a crazy high burst. Then she has a slow, and a damage reduction. I would slow Kat whenever I saw her so even if she Shunpo'd, she wasn't getting far. I would damage reduce their ADC's (Riven, Lucian, etc) as they were engaging. If Kat started her ult, I'd saved my ult just for her so now she's dancing. And then she dies.

"Get randoms to cooperate?" Then you just ping Kat whenever you see her. Your team wants her dead as much as you do.

You don't give random players enough credit. I've played probably almost 20 Hexakill matches and only lost 2. Every match we've been up against a katarina. In one of the ones we lost, it wasn't the kat that beat us. It was actually the akali...

And in how many did you have a Kat on your team as well?

Still, what I said stands.  Even you admit it.  You were forced into a champion you didn't want to play (because if you have to go with your second pick, you aren't getting the champ you wanted), and then you were still forced into items specifically to give you enough time to ult the Kat so you could hope your teammates burned her down.

When, as I stated above, they could have just been REASONABLE and allowed us to ban 3 champions per team.  IF FOR NO OTHER REASON than to not have to see a Kat every damn game, and Yi in almost as many.

I was not forced into a champ I didn't want to play. I played Sona because I DID want to play her and then I realized after my first hexakill match that Sona countered kat well. So I stuck with her. I love being the healer and I love shutting out champs. If there is one champ in the game that I'm really good at shutting down, I'm having a good time. Secondly, you're ALWAYS "Forced" into items. You have to build the items that counter your opponents' strengths and enhance your own. How is that any different from ANY other match EVER? Your argument here is fallacious.

How many did I have a kat on my team? A few, not all of them and as with any game you have those times where you ask why enemy kat seems to be doing better than your kat. all the normal stuff.

You're trying really hard to defend this stance and that's fine. I agree that pick/ban would help much like it did in Ascension. I'm not arguing that. I'm just saying that Kat isn't as hard to counter as you've made her out to be. Yi, I find, is much more difficult to counter simply because of Alpha Strike being so strong. He's untargetable and dealing a large amount of damage and continues to do so when he stops alpha-ing. He can usually start his alpha strike before my DMG nerf power chord hits him, so then it's wasted and he still deals big damage.

Last night, I lost to a team comprised of a Master Yi, a Xin Zhao, a Ryze, a Renekton, a Blitzcrank, and a Sona. No Kat.

there was a Kat on my team. 
She went 12/11/22.

It's all about team coordination. Every game. My team had poor coordination and I wasn't at the top of my game, either. So even when we had a Kat and they didn't, they still stomped us.

"Just pick your favorite and don't lock in right away. If you don't see any CC on your team, switch to your next favorite champ that has some CC."

That's you.  By definition, if you pick your choice champ, then are forced to play a second choice, you are playing something you originally did not want to play.  If what you really meant to say was, "Well, sucks for you if your favorite champ doesn't counter what is strong," then that is what you should have said.

As I said, from the beginning, I'm not even talking about specifically Kat.  I don't think she is the biggest problem.  I do think that people who do think she is should have the right to ban her.  Hell, even I would ban her just to keep the game from going stale, because I saw at least one Kat literally every game I played.

As for your example, Yi is a bigger problem than Kat.  I said so myself.  Though maybe that wasn't in reply to you.  I forget.  My point is that featured game modes should have bans.
I already agreed that bans would be fine seeing how well they worked in Ascension. The rest of that is just you arguing against me because you want me to be wrong.
Actually, the rest of that was a quote, from you, showing that you changed your claims because you realized the first one was idiotic.  Don't bother replying.  I block morons once I'm done with them.
You really know how to lose a discussion with grace. Let me know how that blocking-thing goes.

> So... Pick the right champions, build the right items, AND get a team of randoms to work together.  Yeah, that's the definition of healthy counterplay.

It.... is.... though...

Like that's literally how this game works. With every champion.

Up against a vayne? better pick a lane bully adc
Up against a fed leblanc? Build banshees veil.
Up against a mundo and no one has ignite (Take ignite) Prolly ought ot have your midlane build a morello's.

This idea of "teamwork" and "co-ordination" and "counter-picking" and "itemization" is literally how this game is played.

No, having ONE of those routes to stop someone is healthy counterplay.  Having to use all three simultaneously isn't.  Funny how all your examples in your response have ONE answer that works.  They are all either/or situations.  Katarina in Hexakill, along with a few other champs, requires the right picks, the right items, AND the team coordination to keep her locked down.

How is that at all the same as "Oh, they picked Mundo... guess I better take ignite."  If it were "guess I better build Morellonomicon, take ignite, AND hope my Tristana uses her heal reduction, but doesn't stack it with mine" then it would be similar.

Yeah.  I don't think Kat is the only problem, or even the biggest problem in TT Hexakill, but seriously... why did we not get bans for this mode?  It's ridiculous.  The game isn't balanced around six people, so we should get to ban people that are so much better in the clusterfuck that is 12 people on a small map.

it's actually the map size and the number of players that makes kat stronger here than rift.

Small map = AoE mage heaven from 12 man fights occuring a lot more often
More players = more resets occuring = more AoE

plus, because of the sheer number of people on the map versus the limited resources, you also get a heavily imbalanced power distribution across teams. likely the person who gave first blood will now remain level 3 when the highest on his team is 5 and the rest are 4. Levels ramp up slowly with natural growth, and because of that, snowballers become gods. And what is kat if not a snowballer?
